curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Solve a range of problems involving rates and ratios, with and without digital technologies

keyConcepts.name: Ratio notation and language
keyConcepts.description: Understanding a:b notation, 'a to b', part-to-part vs part-to-whole

keyConcepts.name: Simplifying ratios
keyConcepts.description: Using HCF to reduce ratios to simplest form, including decimals and fractions

keyConcepts.name: Equivalent ratios
keyConcepts.description: Multiplying/dividing both parts by the same number to create equivalent ratios

keyConcepts.name: Dividing quantities in a ratio
keyConcepts.description: Finding total parts, calculating share of each part

keyConcepts.name: Unitary method
keyConcepts.description: Finding the value of one unit to scale up or down

keyConcepts.name: Rate notation and language
keyConcepts.description: Understanding 'per', units like km/h, $/kg, rate as a comparison of different quantities

keyConcepts.name: Unit rates
keyConcepts.description: Finding the rate for one unit (per 1 kg, per 1 hour, etc.)

keyConcepts.name: Comparing rates (best buys)
keyConcepts.description: Using unit rates to compare value for money

keyConcepts.name: Speed, distance, time
keyConcepts.description: Using S = D/T formula, converting units, multi-step problems

keyConcepts.name: Complex rate problems
keyConcepts.description: Multi-step problems combining rates and ratios, average speed, work rate problems

commonMisconceptions.correction: Order is critical - the first number corresponds to the first quantity mentioned

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Adding the same number to both parts keeps the ratio equivalent
commonMisconceptions.correction: You must multiply or divide both parts by the same number

commonMisconceptions.misconception: A ratio of 3:5 means there are 3 and 5 items
commonMisconceptions.correction: 3:5 means 3 parts and 5 parts - total is 8 parts

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Confusing ratio (comparison) with fraction (part of whole)
Rate and ratio are the same thing
commonMisconceptions.correction: Rates compare different units (km/h), ratios compare same units (boys:girls)
Average speed = total distance / total time (not arithmetic mean of speeds)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Mixing up multiplication and division when scaling rates
commonMisconceptions.correction: If rate is 'per hour', multiply by hours to get total; divide total by hours to get rate

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Not converting units before comparing rates
commonMisconceptions.correction: Must have same units (both in $/100g or both in $/kg) before comparing

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Recipe scaling for different serving sizes
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How do you adjust a recipe for 4 people to feed 10?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Supermarket best buys (price per kg comparisons)
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Is the larger packet always better value?
How long will it take to drive to the coast?
How many GB will you use streaming a 2-hour movie?
How much yen will you get for $500 AUD?
How do you mix the perfect shade of orange?
Is 150 bpm a good workout pace for a teenager?
How far apart are two cities that are 3 cm apart on a map?

scaffoldingSequence: Phase 2: Dividing quantities in ratios, unitary method
Phase 3: Rate concepts (unit rates, best buys, speed-distance-time basics)
Phase 4: Complex multi-step problems, average speed, combining rates and ratios

behavioralScience.cognitiveLoadNotes: Introduce ratios with concrete examples (sharing lollies) before abstract notation. Use visual bar models for dividing in ratios.
engagementStrategies: Connect to sports statistics (goals per game)
Use recipe scaling for cooking enthusiasts
Connect speed problems to actual journeys students might take
motivationFactors: Real savings from best buy calculations

difficultyProgression.level1: Simple ratios (2:3), simplify by inspection, basic rate reading
difficultyProgression.level2: Ratios with larger numbers, dividing quantities, finding unit rates
difficultyProgression.level3: Multi-step ratio problems, comparing rates, speed-distance-time
difficultyProgression.level4: Average speed, rates with unit conversion, complex word problems
